headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. I will be your conference facilitator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the SCANA Corporation Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference c
componenttext:
Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. I will be your conference facilitator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the SCANA Corporation Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded on Thursday, February 19, 2015. Anyone who does not consent to the taping may drop off the line.
At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Susan Wright, Director of Financial Planning and Investor Relations.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome to our analyst call. As you know, earlier today, we announced financial results for the fourth quarter and full year 2014. Joining us on the call today are Jimmy Addison, SCANA's Chief Financial Officer; and Steve Byrne, Chief Opera
componenttext:
Thank you, and welcome to our analyst call. As you know, earlier today, we announced financial results for the fourth quarter and full year 2014. Joining us on the call today are Jimmy Addison, SCANA's Chief Financial Officer; and Steve Byrne, Chief Operating Officer of SCE&G. During the call Jimmy will provide an overview of our financial results and related matters, and Steve will provide an update on our new nuclear project. After our comments, we will respond to your questions. Slides and the earnings release referenced to in this call are available at scana.com.
Additionally, we post information related to our new nuclear project directly and other investor relations information directly to our website at scana.com. On SCANA's home page, there is a yellow box containing links to the new nuclear development and other investor relations and updates. It is possible that some of the information that we will be posting from time to time may be deemed material information that is not otherwise been public. You can sign up for email alerts under the Investor Relations section of scana.com to notify you when there is a new posting in the new nuclear development and/or other investor relations information section of the website.
Finally, before I turn the call over to Jimmy, I would like to remind you that certain statements that may be made during today's call are considered forward-looking statements and are subject to a number of risks and uncertainties, as shown on Slide 2. The company does not recognize an obligation to update any forward-looking statements.
Additionally, we may disclose certain non-GAAP measures during this presentation, and the required Reg G information can be found on the Investor Relations section of our website. I'll now turn the call over to Jimmy.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Susan, and thank you all for joining us today. I'll begin our earnings discussion on Slide 3. Basic earnings in the fourth quarter of 2014 were $0.73 per share, consistent with the same period of the prior year. Overall, electric margins increased
componenttext:
Thanks, Susan, and thank you all for joining us today. I'll begin our earnings discussion on Slide 3. Basic earnings in the fourth quarter of 2014 were $0.73 per share, consistent with the same period of the prior year. Overall, electric margins increased during the fourth quarter of 2014 versus the same quarter of the prior year due primarily to continued recovery of financing costs through the Base Load Review Act, or BLRA, and customer growth.
As a reminder, the electric weather normalization pilot ended in December 2013, and the company's financial results for 2014 and going forward are now impacted by abnormal weather in our electric business.
Accordingly, during the fourth quarter of 2014, we estimate that weather had a negative impact of $0.02 on electric margins versus the fourth quarter of the prior year. Additionally, higher gas margins and a slight decrease in the company's effective tax rate also contributed in the quarter. These increases were offset by expected increases in operations and maintenance expenses and CapEx-related items, including depreciation, interest expense as well as share dilution.
Please turn to Slide 4. Basic earnings per share for the year ended December 31, 2014, were $3.79 per share versus $3.40 per share in 2013. Increases in electric and gas margins as well as the decreases in the effective tax rate were partially offset by operations and maintenance expenses and higher expenses and dilution related to our capital program. For the full year of 2014, we estimate weather added $0.21 per share to electric margins versus the prior year.
Now on Slide 5, I'd like to briefly review results for our principal lines of business. South Carolina Electric and Gas Company's full year earnings denoted in blue were up $0.41 per share for 2014 compared to the prior year. This was driven largely by increases in electric margins, which were due primarily to abnormal weather, plus the continued recovery of financing costs through the BLRA and customer growth.
Higher gas margins also contributed to the earnings improvement. These increases were partially offset by increases in O&M expenses, expenses related to our capital program, including property taxes, interest expense and depreciation, as well as share dilution. For the fourth quarter, basic earnings per share were $0.02 higher than in the same period last year.
PSNC Energy's earnings shown in red were $0.39 per share for the full year of 2014 compared to $0.37 per share in the prior year. This increase is mainly attributable to customer growth. For the fourth quarter of 2014, basic earnings were $0.16 per share, consistent with 2013.
SCANA Energy, our retail natural gas marketing business in Georgia, in green, showed an increase in earnings per share of $0.01 over last year. This is mainly due to increased margins from higher throughput during the first and fourth quarters of 2014. As a reminder, the increased margins in the first quarter were partially offset by higher commodity prices experienced in serving the incremental volumes and price competition. For the fourth quarter of 2014, basic earnings per share were also up $0.01 over the same period of 2013.
SCANA's corporate and other businesses reported  a loss of $0.03 per share in the fourth quarter of 2014 compared to near breakeven results in the fourth quarter of the prior year. For the 12-month period, these businesses reported a loss of $0.01 per share in 2014 compared to earnings of $0.04 per share in 2013. This change is primarily the result of higher interest expense at the holding company due to the accelerated amortization of debt issuance costs associated with hybrid securities that were called at par in early 2015 prior to their maturity.
On Slide 6, we have provided 2 years of historical financial data on the 2 subsidiary sales we recently announced to assist in updating your models. The CGT transaction closed on January 31 and the SCI transaction is scheduled to close shortly. To recap, these transactions will generate approximately $650 million of gross proceeds. Our updated estimate of the net cash available to fund our expansion will exceed $425 million after taxes. I will discuss the planned changes to our financing plan shortly.
I would now like to touch on economic trends in our service territory. As you can see on Slide 7, during 2014, company's announced plans to invest over $1 billion with the expectation of creating over 7,500 jobs in our Carolinas territories. At the bottom of the slide, you can see the national unemployment rate, along with the rates for the 3 states where SCANA has a presence and the SCE&G  electric territory. South Carolina's unemployment rate is now at 6.5%, and the rate in SCE&G's electric territory is estimated at 5.6%.
At the top of Slide 8, you can see the South Carolina unemployment statistics as of December 2014 and 2013. Although the South Carolina unemployment rate only dropped 1/10th [ph] of a percentage point from the end of 2013, December of 2014 marked all-time highs for the numbers of South Carolinians employed and in the labor force. The nearly 50,000 additions to the workforce represent a 2.4% increase over December 2013 levels. In short, the expansion of the economy has clearly motivated many that had removed themselves from actively seeking work back into the workforce.
The December market numbers from the South Carolina Association of Realtors showed increases in new listing, pending sales and median sales prices while available housing inventories shrank. I also wanted to mention, as depicted at the bottom of the slide, that United Van Lines recently released its annual movers study for 2014, which tracks migration patterns state to state. Once again, South Carolina and North Carolina ranked second and third, respectively, in terms of domestic migration destinations, corroborating our realized customer growth statistics. These are all very positives signs for our territories.
Slide 9 presents customer growth and electric sales statistics. On the top of the slide are the customer growth rates for each of our regulated businesses. We continue to see strong customer growth in our businesses and in the region. SCE&G's electric business added customers at an annual rate of 1.4%. Our regulated gas businesses in North and South Carolina added customers at 2.5% and 2.8%, respectively. Of particular note is the fact that all of these rates accelerated during the year.
The bottom table outlines our actual and weather-normalized kilowatt hour sales for the 12 months ended December 31, 2014. Overall, weather-normalized total retail sales were up 0.6% on a 12-month ended basis, driven mainly by strong industrial demand. We continue to see slightly lower weather-normalized consumption at the residential level, reflecting anticipated energy efficiencies.
Now please turn to Slide 10, which recaps our regulatory rate base and returns. The pie chart on the left presents the components of our regulated rate base of approximately $8.9 billion. As denoted in the 2 shades of blue, approximately 85% of this rate base is related to the electric business.
In the block on the right, you will see SCE&G's base electric businesses in which we are allowed a 10.25% return on equity. The earned return for the 12 months ended December 31 in the base electric business is approximately 10%, meeting our stated goal of earning a return of 9% or higher to prevent the need for non-BLRA-related base rate increases during the peak nuclear construction years. We are very pleased with the execution of our strategy.
Continuing down the page. On our new nuclear business, we are allowed an 11% return on equity. As you may recall, the Public Service Commission of South Carolina approved our 2014 request for revised rates under the BLRA, which add an incremental of approximately $561 million to our rate base and increased rates by approximately 2.8% in November.
Our regulated gas businesses in Carolinas continued to perform well. We're allowed a return on equity of 10.6% and 10.25% in North and South Carolina, respectively. And we continue to operate these businesses within a reasonable range of those returns. As a reminder, in November, SCE&G's gas business implemented a $2.6 million revenue reduction as a result of the rate stabilization act.
Slide 11 presents our CapEx forecast. This forecast has been updated to reflect our most current CapEx projections for 2015 and '16 and is now inclusive of our 2017 estimates. Note that this forecast excludes CGT and SCI, as the sale of CGT has been completed and the transaction for SCI is expected to close by the end of this quarter. Also, this forecast reflects the company's current estimate of new nuclear spending through 2017, which is updated from what was filed in our quarterly BLRA report.
The data in the BLRA reports are limited to the last approved order by this Public Service Commission in South Carolina and are not always consistent with our new nuclear CapEx expectations. This forecast more actively aligns itself with our anticipated project spending over the next 3 years as it relates to the schedule delay.
At the bottom of the slide, we've recapped the new nuclear CWIP from July 1 through June 30 to correspond to the periods on which the BLRA rate increases are calculated.
Now please turn to Slide 12. To summarize our financings for 2014, on May 27, SCE&G issued $300 million of 50-year bonds at 4.5%. On the equity side, we issued approximately $100 million from our 401(k) matching and drip plans. Looking forward, we revised our estimated financing plan through 2019. While these are our best estimates of incremental debt and equity issuances, it's unlikely that these issuances will occur exactly as presented as they are change in our funding needs for public expenses.
This plan contemplates both the estimated base and the timing of the disbursements related to the new nuclear project as well as deployment of the proceeds from the sale of the subsidiaries. As mentioned in our press release, the plan is to use the cash proceeds, net of taxes from the sales of subs, to displace equity issuances. However, until we can fully deploy the proceeds for that purpose, we're taking advantage of this infusion of cash.
Earlier this month, SCANA redeemed, in advance of maturity, at par its $150 million 2009 Series A 7.7% enhanced junior subordinated notes. In addition, we have delayed long-term debt issuances and are reducing our short-term borrowings. We also turned off the issuance of new shares to supply our 401k and DRIP plans earlier this year and anticipate delaying the need for any additional equity issuances until 2017. We don't currently project the need for any additional equity beyond the new shares provided by the use of 401(k) and the DRIP plan, which we will turn on an as needed.
Overall, we continue to adjust the financing to match the related CapEx on a 50-50 debt and equity basis. Obviously, the construction delay has slowed expenditures, but they were also significantly reduced by lower-than-anticipated escalation. The delay is a matter of timing, but the escalation on those components already received or completed will result in permanent savings. Any change in the amount or timing of the new nuclear cost would obviously result in a change in this plan.
I would now like to discuss our 2015 earnings guidance and related assumptions as shown on Slide 13. First, as you can see on the top left slide, we are resetting our base here for our long-term GAAP adjusted average annual growth guidance of 3% to 6% over the next 3 to 5 years off of 2014's GAAP adjusted weather-normalized EPS of $3.58 per share. Our 2015 operating plan, exclusive of the gains on the sale of the 2 subsidiaries, would have resulted in $3.74 per share. However, we project the 2015 earnings will be negatively impacted by $0.04 per share due to the short-term impact of these 2 sales.
While these transactions are expected to yield approximately $0.04 per share of accretion on the long-term basis, all of the proceeds can't be officially deployed in the short run to displace equity needs. As such, we believe there will be downward pressure on 2015's expected earnings, which is considered in our guidance. Therefore, our 2015 net internal target for GAAP adjusted earnings is $3.70 per share. Our GAAP adjusted earnings per share guidance is $3.60 to $3.80 per share.
Due to the cyclical nature of our business, we expect to earn approximately 30% of this amount in the first quarter, approximately 25% in each the third and fourth quarters, and the remaining 20% in the second quarter. In computing this guidance range, we have included the impact of a base rate increase from our new nuclear filing under the BLRA, the 2014 gas RSA filing and our view of the economy. This guidance also incorporates the CapEx and financing plans we presented earlier. We continue to assume customer average use of electricity will be slightly lower this year as energy efficiency trends continue to work their way into the market.
We anticipate overall weather-normalized retail electric sales growth for 2015 to decline by approximately 0.6%. We forecast electric customer growth to be similar to 2014.
Operation and maintenance expenses are expected to be relatively flat in 2015 compared to 2014 actuals. Our effective tax rate for 2014 was slightly less than 32%. And we estimate the rate for 2015, exclusive of the taxes on the gains of the sales of the subsidiaries, will be approximately 31%. Hopefully this will provide you with a line of sight into our view of 2015 as you update your models.
Finally, I will mention that earlier today, we announced an increase in our annual dividend rate for 2015 of $0.08 to $2.18 per share, a 3.8% increase. The results of 2014 and confidence in the long-term strategy were key considerations. We continue to anticipate growing dividends, fairly consistent with earnings, while staying within our stated payout policy of 55% to 60%.
I'll now turn the call over to Steve to provide an update on our nuclear project.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jimmy. I want to begin by recapping the preliminary new nuclear construction schedule on cost information we received from the Consortium. As described last week at our quarterly update filing with the Public Service Commission of South Carolina,
componenttext:
Thanks, Jimmy. I want to begin by recapping the preliminary new nuclear construction schedule on cost information we received from the Consortium. As described last week at our quarterly update filing with the Public Service Commission of South Carolina, the Consortium has indicated a substantial completion date for Unit 2 is expected to occur by June of 2019 and a substantial completion date for Unit 3 may be approximately 12 months later. We are continuing our discussions with the Consortium in order to identify potential strategies to possibly accelerate the substantial completion date of Unit 2 to a time earlier in the first half of 2019 or to the end of 2018 with the Unit 3 following approximately 12 months later.
As Jimmy previously mentioned, we are in the midst of process with the Consortium, and we cannot predict when the revised schedule and cost estimates will be resolved. Further, neither SCE&G nor Santee Cooper has accepted the new preliminary schedule or financial responsibility associated with these delays. We anticipate filing a petition requesting an adjustment to our current capital cost and construction schedules with the Public Service Commission before the end of this quarter.
Under the BLRA, the Public Service Commission would then have 6 months to issue its order.
I would now like to discuss some of the activities at the new nuclear construction site. On Slide 14, you can see an aerial photo of the site from December. I have labeled both units 2 and 3 as well as many other areas that make up the construction tabletop. And as you can see, progress continues to take place on the project.
Slide 15 shows where some of the module fabrication has been moved from CB&I's Lake Charles facility to various other venues in the United states and Japan. Fabrication of the CA-03 submodules continues at the SMCI facility in Florida. Newport industries in Virginia is fabricating and continues to ship building to the site. works and Toshiba operation are the principal fabricators for Unit 3's CA20 and CA-01 submodules, respectively.
On Slide 16, you can see a picture of the Unit 2 nuclear island. In this picture, you can see modules CA20 along with the containment vessel Ring 1, which has been placed on the containment vessel lower bowl. The lower bowl is now covered by the auxiliary building walls as they are coming up to what we call elevation 100, which is about 35 feet above the base mat. Once elevation 100 has been reached, work will begin on the annex building, which will house the electrical switch gear for the plant.
Slide 17 shows the schematic of the module inside the containment vessel. And here, you can see the locations of modules CA-01, 02, 03 and 05, which we'll further discuss shortly.
Slide 18 has an exploded view of CA-01 through 05 showing where they fit in the containment vessel.
Slide 19 shows a recent picture of Unit 2 module CA-01. CA-01 houses the generator, pressure and forms of fuel canal inside the containment vessel. We currently have all 47 submodules on-site, and 34 of those submodules are upright and being assembled in the Module Assembly Building or MAB.
Slide 20 is a shipment from Yokohama, Japan, of the first Unit 3 CA-01 submodule fabricated by Toshiba, which should be on-site in early March.
Slide 21 shows pictures of the Unit 2 module CA-05. This module comprises one of the major wall sections within the containment vessel. On the top right, you can see module CA-05 inside of the tent where the final wells are prior to placement. On December 6, 2014, this model was lifted with the Heavy Lift Derrick as seen on the left-hand side of the slide, in place in the containment vessel as seen in the bottom right-hand of this slide.
On Slide 22, you can see an aerial picture with a good view of the containment vessel rings that are currently being fabricated for units 2 and 3. As you can see on the bottom, the Unit 2 containment vessel ring 1 has been placed on top of the lower and ring 2 is complete and will be set after placement of structural module CA-01. Across the top of the picture, you can see 3 other containment vessel rings that are in the process of being fabricated for units 2 and 3. it has a total of 3 brings such -- in addition, the steel for the Unit 2 containment vessel top closure head is also on site.
Slide 23 shows a picture of the Unit 3 nuclear island. Here, you can see where the containment vessel lower bowl has been placed, and the ancillary walls continue to take [indiscernible].
On Slide 24, you can see an aerial picture showing the full profile cleaning power. Cooling tower is [indiscernible] both structurally complete and you can see the progress continuing on 2 and 3 Bravo.
On Slide 25, you can see 1 of the 2 steam generators unit 2 that arrives in the construction site for January. The component was transported from the Port of Charleston by rail on a specifically designed car. This steam generally weighs 1.3 million pounds. It's about 20 feet in diameter, and it's almost 82 feet long.
Slide 26 shows building panels for Unit 2. the buildings around the containment vessel. These panels will be welded together and concrete will be poured inside the panels to create a shield. on the left, you can view of the panels up close and the right, you can see it made on the yard where we have begun receiving the panels. We currently have received 44 of the 167 Unit 2 panels that are provided by industries.
I wanted also to briefly mention the 8-inch explosive or belts, which are a key component of the state the system if you want come back designed a recently passed series of a engineering test to determine if they will properly operating under extreme conditions such as high-pressure temperature. This great news for the project is for testing the qualified for them for.
On Slide 27, you will see the new nuclear CapEx actual and projected over the life of construction. This chart also reflects our company's current actual and estimated new nuclear CapEx during the years 2008 to 2020, which previously discussed is updated from we filed in the latest chapter of report. As you can see, the next several years are the in the construction period. The green line represents related [indiscernible] customer rate increases under the BLRA and is associated with the right-hand access. As a reminder, the incremental 5% future acquisition of the new nuclear project [indiscernible] an effect on these protected BLRA 
please now turn to Slide 28. [indiscernible] For in September calling, the public rate issued a release of $2 million, [ph] the new rates are effective to those rendered on or after September 30. Our BLRA filings [indiscernible] are shown at the bottom of the fly and you can see we recently filed our quarterly status report for the fourth quarter.
That concludes our prepared remarks. We'll now be glad to respond to any questions you might have.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hey, quick question for you. In the press release, you talked about the interest savings on the nuclear project. Am I thinking about this correctly that you have roughly $1.2 billion in potential interest rate savings versus the original project costs? So
componenttext: Hey, quick question for you. In the press release, you talked about the interest savings on the nuclear project. Am I thinking about this correctly that you have roughly $1.2 billion in potential interest rate savings versus the original project costs? So if that stay on plan, and let's assume a worst-case scenario where there's $660 million construction dispute it goes against you -- the entire thing so that's a real worst-case basis. Does that mean you're still under the original project cost and you're going to wind up -- and the customers are not going to be impacted in anyway?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I appreciate the question. And this is really the first we've emphasized those savings. So we really like to clarify some misunderstanding, some in the bench markets and some in the local area here where our folks really weren't understanding the es
componenttext: Well, I appreciate the question. And this is really the first we've emphasized those savings. So we really like to clarify some misunderstanding, some in the bench markets and some in the local area here where our folks really weren't understanding the escalation savings. So we're projecting, as you know, in the BLRA somewhere around $575 million of lower escalation today than when we originally started the project. And sometimes that had been confused with lower financing costs. The lower escalation is just lower escalation on the actual labor and modules, et cetera, associated with the construction, has nothing to do with the financing cost. So what we put in the press release is our estimate of the estimated savings over the tenure of the bonds that we have issued and those that we have locked in, the savings that would occur over the life of those. So they're really 2 different matters. As far as your real question about -- would the $660 million be offset by the $1.2 billion, [ph] I paid really be offset dollar by dollar by the escalations savings because those are more in today's dollars, the $1.2 billion [ph] are savings to occur over the future of the bonds some 30-plus years.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: We -- you're looking at for -- quarter, I think 2 things. one of them was the burn rate for owner's costs and another one was for financing costs. On the owner's cost, I think you can assume we're very similar to them. The financing costs, however, their
componenttext: We -- you're looking at for -- quarter, I think 2 things. one of them was the burn rate for owner's costs and another one was for financing costs. On the owner's cost, I think you can assume we're very similar to them. The financing costs, however, their structure in Georgia, their contracts, the way they finance a little different than the way we're financing. So I don't think you can make the assumption of financing costs. But on the owner's cost, the burn rate that they quotes, you can use roughly the same numbers for us.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. And also, separate topic. The South Carolina distributed energy resource program, is there any opportunities for you guys to participate in solar bills, regulated solar bills in South Carolina?
componenttext: Right. And also, separate topic. The South Carolina distributed energy resource program, is there any opportunities for you guys to participate in solar bills, regulated solar bills in South Carolina?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, there may be some opportunity. That's all being sorted out now. There's process in front of the commission at this time. So there may be some opportunity in there, but it's real pay. That's limited -- the whole legislation is aimed for South Carolina
componenttext: Yes, there may be some opportunity. That's all being sorted out now. There's process in front of the commission at this time. So there may be some opportunity in there, but it's real pay. That's limited -- the whole legislation is aimed for South Carolina as a state to get some good experience with renewables, not just solar but with renewables in general. And the goal is for the requirement really is for 2% to be -- 2% of our generation to be in distributed, 1% utility, 1% in customer scale, by 2020. So -- and we think those are a challenge to get done, but we think we will get them done. But there may be a small opportunity for us to participate in it. I expect there will be, but I don't think it will be material to our financial results.

componenttext: This is Steve. The implications that we have to go through a formal hearing process, which is what the application that we would file by the end of the quarter kicks off. So in between then and 6 months later when an order has to be issued, we'll have a hearing. And that hearing will have our opportunity to explain what happened with the Public Service Commission. It would have to really in before they would deny it and imprudent of utility, which I think they do very difficult for everybody to prove. And we have done this once before. So we've asked for line of our schedule, once in the past and that was approved by the Public Service Commission by a 7-0 [ph] vote.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015

componenttextpreview: I'm not sure it would be a gating factor. I'm not sure exactly what they might do with it. I don't think it would be fair to assume they would just say no. But it is a hearing process and we will have to make our case for why the schedule extension is rea
componenttext: I'm not sure it would be a gating factor. I'm not sure exactly what they might do with it. I don't think it would be fair to assume they would just say no. But it is a hearing process and we will have to make our case for why the schedule extension is reasonable, which, certainly, we think we can make. But we'll be asking for what we pointed out today, so those new schedules. So this is our opportunity to explain that to the commission because we're not allowed to have conversation with them outside of this formal hearing or an briefing process.

componenttext: That's correct. and maybe I can just summarize another way. 1 strategy we could have deployed is to take all the cash and go out and buy back shares today. We didn't think that made the losses given the valuation of the industry sector, given prices of stock today to go out and buy stock today and then go sell shares again 12, 18 months later. But just to try to clear that up, I said about going through that.

componenttext: Yes, so the best way to get the money back is not to pay it in the first place. headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The next question comes from Michael Lapides from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The next question comes from Michael Lapides from Goldman Sachs.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me just try I understand 1 thing. I got a little bit used to when discussing payments, including or not including part of the $660 million. The thing I want to make sure is, is the number -- the total number in the CapEx slide that you're showing toda
componenttext: Let me just try I understand 1 thing. I got a little bit used to when discussing payments, including or not including part of the $660 million. The thing I want to make sure is, is the number -- the total number in the CapEx slide that you're showing today, is that a bigger number than what you showed in the prior quarter slide or is that the exact same number?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think what you're looking at is a 3-year look at CapEx. And if you look at the 3-year period, the numbers are very close. They're different though in every year. So we've moved the cost around. And what you don't see in the 3-year look is the expa
componenttext: Well, I think what you're looking at is a 3-year look at CapEx. And if you look at the 3-year period, the numbers are very close. They're different though in every year. So we've moved the cost around. And what you don't see in the 3-year look is the expansion out for a couple of more years. So now instead of running through 2018 or 2019, we're now running through 2020. So in the 3-year look, you don't necessarily see that. So what we've included in the capital forecast going forward would be where we see the normal construction process and our payments based on the Consortium achieving milestones. And we've added what we're estimating for increases in owner's costs and change orders that we would not dispute. There are some things, like cyber security. Cyber security rules were not around when the contract was negotiated. They've changed so we have to account for that. So wouldn't necessarily dispute the fact that we would have to pay for cyber. And so that would be it an exact change we would include in the file that we've got coming up. So to the extent that those cost would be in those next 3 years that would be in what you're seeing. And we've included a number of escalation on our owner's cost, and what you would call a minimal amount of entitlement. So of that 660, there's a portion of that, that we said, we probably would not dispute that so we've included that in the cost. But to -- not to buy our negotiating position among them to say exactly what that this.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, our contract has traditional change order type language. So a force majeure would trigger change orders. Certainly, if it was a change in the regulation, then they would be entitled to a change order. And a good example of that would be cyber securit
componenttext: Yes, our contract has traditional change order type language. So a force majeure would trigger change orders. Certainly, if it was a change in the regulation, then they would be entitled to a change order. And a good example of that would be cyber security. The regulation changed, so we've amended the contract to account for that. And it will cost us a little bit more for cyber security. Where we would perhaps differ with the Consortium is their interpretation of what's called a regulatory-driven change, and we would not accept that that's a change in the regulation. So we are at odds over that topic.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So to make sure I don't further confuse this, let me go back. So what we've been presenting in each BLRA would be the total projected cost each time we file the report each quarter for our 55% share. And we originally, of course, were approved for $6
componenttext: Yes. So to make sure I don't further confuse this, let me go back. So what we've been presenting in each BLRA would be the total projected cost each time we file the report each quarter for our 55% share. And we originally, of course, were approved for $6.3 billion in total future estimated costs. And our current projections are just over $0.5 billion less than that, about $575 million less. All of those reports to date have been focused on the lower escalation, if you will, the lower inflation during the construction period that the Consortium was entitled to bill us for based upon publicly available indices associated with the construction. What we put in our press release today has nothing to do with that. That is the financing costs once the Consortium bills us with whatever the escalation is, how do we go out and finance it on the debt side? So the equity side is fairly straightforward, 50% of it financed through equity the BLRA and 11% ROE. The 50% refinance with debt, were doing with first mortgage bonds. We had originally estimated in our BLRA filing based upon our embedded cost of debt at that time, a debt cost of about 6.4%, whereas overall we issued bonds at slightly under 5% live to date on the project. And all of those are fixed-rate bonds. And so what we've disclosed is we estimate that the savings on those over the life of the bonds will be $700 million, about $20 million a year. And then additional bonds that we expect to issue in the next 2 years that we've already hedged the rate on, we estimate to save another $525 million [ph] on those over the life of those bonds. So that's the $1,225,000,000 [ph] in interest savings that we expect to incur over the life of those savings. Completely independent of the escalation to lower inflation on the construction itself.

So we updated most of our experience each year and at this point, we still feel like it's our best estimate.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you. 2014 was certainly a very unusual year relative to weather. But aside from the weather, we're very pleased with our underlying economic growth, the operation of our businesses and the refinement of our focus around our core retail busines
componenttext:
Well, thank you. 2014 was certainly a very unusual year relative to weather. But aside from the weather, we're very pleased with our underlying economic growth, the operation of our businesses and the refinement of our focus around our core retail businesses. Accordingly, we're really optimistic about our future.
And finally, I'll mention that Steve and I will be on the road the first week of March in New York and Boston at investor conferences, and we hope to see many of you there. Thank you for joining us today and for your interest in SCANA.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. I will be your conference facilitator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the SCANA Corporation conference call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference c
componenttext:
Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. I will be your conference facilitator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the SCANA Corporation conference call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded on Thursday, February 19, 2015. Anyone who does not consent to the taping may drop off the line.
At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Susan Wright, Director of Financial Planning and Investor Relations.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome to our analyst call. As you know, earlier today, we announced financial results for the fourth quarter and full year 2014. Joining us on the call today are Jimmy Addison, SCANA's Chief Financial Officer; and Steve Byrne, Chief Opera
componenttext:
Thank you, and welcome to our analyst call. As you know, earlier today, we announced financial results for the fourth quarter and full year 2014. Joining us on the call today are Jimmy Addison, SCANA's Chief Financial Officer; and Steve Byrne, Chief Operating Officer of SCE&G. During the call, Jimmy will provide an overview of our financial results and related matters, and Steve will provide an update on our new nuclear project. After our comments, we will respond to your questions. Slides and the earnings release referenced to in this call are available at scana.com.
Additionally, we post information related to our new nuclear project and other investor relations information directly to our website at scana.com. On SCANA's home page, there is a yellow box containing links to the new nuclear development and Other Investor Information section of the website. It is possible that some of the information that we will be posting from time to time may be deemed material information that is not otherwise become public. You can sign up for email alerts under the Investor Relations section of scana.com to notify you when there is a new posting in the new nuclear development and/or Other Investor Relations information section of the website.
Finally, before I turn the call over to Jimmy, I would like to remind you that certain statements that may be made during today's call are considered forward-looking statements and are subject to a number of risks and uncertainties, as shown on Slide 2. The company does not recognize an obligation to update any forward-looking statements. Additionally, we may disclose certain non-GAAP measures during this presentation, and the required Reg G information can be found on the Investor Relations section of our website.
I'll now turn the call over to Jimmy.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Susan, and thank you all for joining us today. I'll begin our earnings discussion on Slide 3. Basic earnings in the fourth quarter of 2014 were $0.73 per share, consistent with the same period of the prior year. Overall, electric margins increased
componenttext:
Thanks, Susan, and thank you all for joining us today. I'll begin our earnings discussion on Slide 3. Basic earnings in the fourth quarter of 2014 were $0.73 per share, consistent with the same period of the prior year. Overall, electric margins increased during the fourth quarter of 2014 versus the same quarter of the prior year, due primarily to continued recovery of financing costs through the Base Load Review Act, or BLRA, and customer growth.
As a reminder, the electric weather normalization pilot ended in December 2013, and the company's financial results for 2014 and going forward are now impacted by abnormal weather in our electric business.
Accordingly, during the fourth quarter of 2014, we estimate that weather had a negative impact of $0.02 on electric margins versus the fourth quarter of the prior year. Additionally, higher gas margins and a slight decrease in the company's effective tax rate also contributed in the quarter. These increases were offset by expected increases in operations and maintenance expenses and CapEx-related items, including depreciation, interest expense as well as share dilution.
Please turn to Slide 4. Basic earnings per share for the year ended December 31, 2014, were $3.79 per share versus $3.40 per share in 2013. Increases in electric and gas margins, as well as the decreases in the effective tax rate, were partially offset by operations and maintenance expenses and higher expenses and dilution related to our capital program. For the full year of 2014, we estimate weather added $0.21 per share to electric margins versus the prior year.
Now on Slide 5, I'd like to briefly review results for our principal lines of business. South Carolina Electric and Gas Company's full year earnings, denoted in blue, were up $0.41 per share for 2014 compared to the prior year. This was driven largely by increases in electric margins, which were due primarily to abnormal weather, plus the continued recovery of financing costs through the BLRA and customer growth.
Higher gas margins also contributed to the earnings improvement. These increases were partially offset by increases in O&M expenses, expenses related to our capital program, including property taxes, interest expense and depreciation, as well as share dilution. For the fourth quarter, basic earnings per share were $0.02 higher than in the same period last year.
PSNC Energy's earnings, shown in red, were $0.39 per share for the full year of 2014 compared to $0.37 per share in the prior year. This increase is mainly attributable to customer growth. For the fourth quarter of 2014, basic earnings were $0.16 per share, consistent with 2013.
SCANA Energy, our retail natural gas marketing business in Georgia, in green, showed an increase in earnings per share of $0.01 over last year. This is mainly due to increased margins from higher throughput during the first and fourth quarters of 2014. As a reminder, the increased margins in the first quarter were partially offset by higher commodity prices experienced in serving the incremental volumes and price competition. For the fourth quarter of 2014, basic earnings per share were also up $0.01 over the same period of 2013.
SCANA's corporate and other businesses reported a loss of $0.03 per share in the fourth quarter of 2014 compared to near breakeven results in the fourth quarter of the prior year. For the 12-month period, these businesses reported a loss of $0.01 per share in 2014 compared to earnings of $0.04 per share in 2013. This change is primarily the result of higher interest expense at the holding company due to the accelerated amortization of debt issuance costs associated with hybrid securities that were called at par in early 2015 prior to their maturity.
On Slide 6, we have provided 2 years of historical financial data on the 2 subsidiary sales we recently announced to assist in updating your models. The CGT transaction closed on January 31, and the SCI transaction is scheduled to close shortly. To recap, these transactions will generate approximately $650 million of gross proceeds. Our updated estimate of the net cash available to fund our expansion will exceed $425 million after taxes. I will discuss the planned changes to our financing plan shortly.
I would now like to touch on the economic trends in our service territory. As you can see on Slide 7, during 2014, companies announced plans to invest over $1 billion with the expectation of creating over 7,500 jobs in our Carolinas territories. At the bottom of the slide, you can see the national unemployment rate, along with the rates for the 3 states where SCANA has a presence, and the SCE&G electric territory. South Carolina's unemployment rate is now at 6.5%, and the rate in SCE&G's electric territory is estimated at 5.6%.
At the top of Slide 8, you can see the South Carolina unemployment statistics as of December 2014 and 2013. Although the South Carolina unemployment rate only dropped 0.10% from the end of 2013, December of 2014 marked all-time highs for the number of South Carolinians employed and in the labor force. The nearly 50,000 additions to the workforce represent a 2.4% increase over December 2013 levels. In short, the expansion of the economy has clearly motivated many that had removed themselves from actively seeking work back into the workforce.
The December market numbers from the South Carolina Association of REALTORS showed increases in new listing, pending sales and median sales prices, while available housing inventory shrank. I also wanted to mention, as depicted at the bottom of the slide, that United Van Lines recently released its annual movers study for 2014, which tracks migration patterns state to state. Once again, South Carolina and North Carolina ranked second and third, respectively, in terms of domestic migration destinations, corroborating our realized customer growth statistics. These are all very positives signs for our territories.
Slide 9 presents customer growth and electric sales statistics. On the top of the slide are the customer growth rates for each of our regulated businesses. We continue to see strong customer growth in our businesses and in the region. SCE&G's electric business added customers at an annual rate of 1.4%. Our regulated gas businesses in North and South Carolina added customers at 2.5% and 2.8%, respectively. Of particular note is the fact that all of these rates accelerated during the year.
The bottom table outlines our actual and weather-normalized kilowatt hour sales for the 12 months ended December 31, 2014. Overall, weather-normalized total retail sales were up 0.6% on a 12-month-ended basis, driven mainly by strong industrial demand. We continue to see slightly lower weather-normalized consumption at the residential level, reflecting anticipated energy efficiencies.
Now please turn to Slide 10, which recaps our regulatory rate base and returns. The pie chart on the left presents the components of our regulated rate base of approximately $8.9 billion. As denoted in the 2 shades of blue, approximately 85% of this rate base is related to the electric business.
In the block on the right, you will see SCE&G's base electric businesses in which we are allowed a 10.25% return on equity. The earned return for the 12 months ended December 31 in the base electric business is approximately 10%, meeting our stated goal of earning a return of 9% or higher to prevent the need for non-BLRA-related base rate increases during the peak nuclear construction years. We are very pleased with the execution of our strategy.
Continuing down the page. On our new nuclear business, we are allowed an 11% return on equity. As you may recall, the Public Service Commission of South Carolina approved our 2014 request for revised rates under the BLRA, which add an incremental quip of approximately $561 million to our rate base and increased rates by approximately 2.8% in November.
Our regulated gas businesses in Carolinas continued to perform well. We're allowed a return on equity of 10.6% and 10.25% in North and South Carolina, respectively. And we continue to operate these businesses within a reasonable range of those returns. As a reminder, in November, SCE&G's gas business implemented a $2.6 million revenue reduction as a result of the Rate Stabilization Act.
Slide 11 presents our CapEx forecast. This forecast has been updated to reflect our most current CapEx projections for 2015 and '16, and is now inclusive of our 2017 estimates. Note that this forecast excludes CGT and SCI, as the sale of CGT has been completed and the transaction for SCI is expected to close by the end of this quarter. Also, this forecast reflects the company's current estimate of new nuclear spending through 2017, which is updated from what was filed in our quarterly BLRA report.
The data in the BLRA reports are limited to the last approved order by the Public Service Commission of South Carolina and are not always consistent with our new nuclear CapEx expectations. This forecast more accurately aligns itself with our anticipated project spending over the next 3 years as it relates to the schedule delay.
At the bottom of the slide, we recapped the new nuclear CWIP from July 1 through June 30 to correspond to the periods on which the BLRA rate increases are calculated.
Now please turn to Slide 12. To summarize our financings for 2014, on May 27, SCE&G issued $300 million of 50-year bonds at 4.5%. On the equity side, we issued approximately $100 million from our 401(k) matching and DRIP plans. Looking forward, we revised our estimated financing plan through 2019. While these are our best estimates of incremental debt and equity issuances, it's unlikely that these issuances will occur exactly as presented as they are subject to changing in our funding needs for planned public expenses.
This plan contemplates both the estimated delays and the timing of the disbursements related to the new nuclear project, as well as deployment of the proceeds from the sale of the subsidiaries. As mentioned in our press release, the plan is to use the cash proceeds, net of taxes from the sales of subs, to displace equity issuances. However, until we can fully deploy the proceeds for that purpose, we're taking advantage of this infusion of cash.
Earlier this month, SCANA redeemed, in advance of maturity, at par, its $150 million 2009 Series A, 7.7% Enhanced Junior Subordinated Notes. In addition, we have delayed long-term debt issuances and are reducing our short-term borrowings. We also turned off the issuance of new shares to supply our 401(k) and DRIP plans earlier this year, and anticipate delaying the need for any additional equity issuances until 2017. We don't currently project the need for any additional equity beyond the new shares provided by the use of 401(k) and the DRIP plan, which we will turn on an as needed.
Overall, we continue to adjust the financing to match the related CapEx on a 50-50 debt and equity basis. Obviously, the construction delay has slowed expenditures, but they were also significantly reduced by lower-than-anticipated escalation. The delay is a matter of timing, but the escalation on those components already received or completed will result in permanent savings. Any change in the amount or timing of the new nuclear cost would obviously result in a change in this plan.
I would now like to discuss our 2015 earnings guidance and related assumptions, as shown on Slide 13. First, as you can see on the top left of the slide, we are resetting our base year for our long-term GAAP-adjusted average annual growth guidance of 3% to 6% over the next 3 to 5 years, off of 2014's GAAP-adjusted weather-normalized EPS of $3.58 per share. Our 2015 operating plan, exclusive of the aggregate gains on the sale of the 2 subsidiaries, would have resulted in $3.74 per share. However, we project the 2015 earnings will be negatively impacted by $0.04 per share due to the short-term impact of these 2 sales.
While these transactions are expected to yield approximately $0.04 per share of accretion on a long-term basis, all of the proceeds can't be officially deployed in the short run to displace equity needs. As such, we believe there will be downward pressure on 2015's expected earnings, which is considered in our guidance. Therefore, our 2015 net internal target for GAAP-adjusted earnings is $3.70 per share. Our GAAP-adjusted earnings per share guidance is $3.60 to $3.80 per share.
Due to the cyclical nature of our business, we expect to earn approximately 30% of this amount in the first quarter, approximately 25% in each the third and fourth quarters, and the remaining 20% in the second quarter. In computing this guidance range, we have included the impact of a base rate increase from our new nuclear filing under the BLRA, the 2014 gas RSA filing and our view of the economy.
This guidance also incorporates the CapEx and financing plans we presented earlier. We continue to assume customer average use of electricity will be slightly lower this year, as energy efficiency trends continue to work their way into the market. We anticipate overall weather-normalized retail electric sales growth for 2015 to decline by approximately 0.6%. We forecast electric customer growth to be similar to 2014.
Operation and maintenance expenses are expected to be relatively flat in 2015 compared to 2014 actuals. Our effective tax rate for 2014 was slightly less than 32%. And we estimate the rate for 2015, exclusive of the taxes on the gains of the sales of the subsidiaries, will be approximately 31%. Hopefully this will provide you with a line of sight into our view of 2015 as you update your models.
Finally, I will mention that earlier today, we announced an increase in our annual dividend rate for 2015 of $0.08 to $2.18 per share, a 3.8% increase. The results of 2014 and confidence in the long-term strategy were key considerations. We continue to anticipate growing dividends, fairly consistent with earnings, while staying within our stated payout policy of 55% to 60%.
I'll now turn the call over to Steve to provide an update on our nuclear project.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jimmy. I wanted to begin by recapping the preliminary new nuclear construction schedule and cost information we received from the Consortium. As described last week at our quarterly BLRA update filing with the Public Service Commission of South Ca
componenttext:
Thanks, Jimmy. I wanted to begin by recapping the preliminary new nuclear construction schedule and cost information we received from the Consortium. As described last week at our quarterly BLRA update filing with the Public Service Commission of South Carolina, the Consortium has indicated the substantial completion date for Unit 2 is expected to occur by June of 2019, and the substantial completion date for Unit 3 may be approximately 12 months later. We are continuing our discussions with the Consortium in order to identify potential mitigation strategies to possibly accelerate the substantial completion date of Unit 2 to a time earlier in the first half of 2019 or to the end of 2018 with Unit 3 following approximately 12 months later.
As Jimmy previously mentioned, we are in the midst of negotiation process with the Consortium, and we cannot predict when the revised schedule and cost estimates will be resolved. Further, neither SCE&G nor Santee Cooper has accepted the new preliminary schedule or financial responsibility associated with these delays. We anticipate filing a petition requesting an adjustment to our current capital cost and construction schedules with the Public Service Commission before the end of this quarter. Under the BLRA, the Public Service Commission would then have 6 months to issue its order.
I would now like to discuss some of the activities at the new nuclear construction site. On Slide 14, you can see an aerial photo of the site from December. I have labeled both units 2 and 3 as well as many other areas that make up the construction tabletop. And as you can see, progress continues to take place on the project.
Slide 15 shows where some of the module fabrication has been moved from CB&I's Lake Charles Louisiana facility to various other venues in the United states and Japan. Fabrication of the CA-03 submodules continues at the SMCI facility in Florida. Newport News Industries in Virginia is fabricating and continues to ship shipbuilding panels to the site. Oregon Iron Works and Toshiba IHI Corporation are the principal fabricators for Unit 3's CA20 and CA-01 submodules, respectively.
On Slide 16, you can see a picture of the Unit 2 nuclear island. In this picture, you can see modules CA20 along with the containment vessel Ring 1, which has been placed on the containment vessel lower bowl. The lower bowl is now covered by the auxiliary building walls as they are coming up to what we call elevation 100, which is about 35 feet above the base mat. Once elevation 100 has been reached, work will begin on the annex building, which will house the electrical switch gear for the plant.
Slide 17 shows the schematic of the module inside the containment vessel. And here, you can see the locations of modules CA-01, 02, 03 and 05, which we'll further discuss shortly.
Slide 18 has an exploded view of CA-01 through 05 showing where they fit spatially in the containment vessel.
Slide 19 shows a recent picture of Unit 2 module CA-01. CA-01 houses the steam generators, the pressurizer and forms a refueling canal inside the containment vessel. We currently have all 47 submodules on site, and 34 of those submodules are upright and being assembled in the Module Assembly Building, or MAB.
Slide 20 is a shipment from Yokohama, Japan, of the first Unit 3 CA-01 submodule fabricated by Toshiba, which should be on site in early March.
Slide 21 shows pictures of the Unit 2 module CA-05. This module comprises one of the major wall sections within the containment vessel. On the top right, you can see module CA-05 inside of the tent where the final wells are completed prior to placement. On December 6, 2014, this model was lifted with the heavy lift derrick, as seen on the left-hand side of the slide; and placed in the containment vessel, as seen in the bottom-right-hand side of this slide.
On Slide 22, you can see an aerial picture with a good view of the containment vessel rings that are currently being fabricated for units 2 and 3. As you can see on the bottom right, the Unit 2 containment vessel Ring 1 has been placed on top of the containment vessel lower bowl, and ring 2 is complete and will be set after placement of structural module CA-01. Across the top of the picture, you can see 3 other containment vessel rings that are in the process of being fabricated for units 2 and 3. Each unit has a total of 3 ring sections. In addition, the steel for the Unit 2 containment vessel top closure head is also on site.
Slide 23 shows a picture of the Unit 3 nuclear island. Here, you can see where the containment vessel lower bowl has been placed, and the auxiliary building walls continue to take form.
On Slide 24, you can see an aerial picture showing the 4 low-profile forced draft cooling towers. The cooling towers, 2 Alpha and 3 Alpha, are both structurally complete and you can see the progress continuing on 2 Bravo and 3 Bravo.
On Slide 25, you can see 1 of the 2 steam generators in Unit 2 that arrived in the construction site on January. The component was transported from the Port of Charleston by rail on a specifically designed Schnabel car. This steam generator weighs approximately 1.3 million pounds. It's about 20 feet in diameter, and it's almost 82 feet long.
Slide 26 shows shipbuilding panels for Unit 2. The shipbuilding surrounds the containment vessel. These panels will be welded together and concrete will be poured inside the panels to create a shipbuilding. On the left, you can see one of the panels up close; and the right, you can see it laid on the yard where we have begun receiving the panels. We currently have received 44 of the 167 Unit 2 panels that are provided by Newport News Industries.
I wanted also to briefly mention the 8-inch explosive, or squib belts, which are a key component of the passive safety system of the AP 1000 design. It recently passed a series of a engineering tests to determine if they will properly operating under extreme conditions, such as high-pressure and temperature. This is great news for the project as is prepares the valves for testing to qualify them for submergence.
On Slide 27, you will see the new nuclear CapEx, actual and projected, over the life of construction. This chart also reflects our company's current actual and estimated new nuclear CapEx during the years 2008 to 2020, which, as Jimmy previously discussed, is updated from where filed in the latest quarterly BLRA report. As you can see, the next several years are the peak nuclear construction period. The green line represents the related actual and projected customer rate increases under the BLRA, and is associated with the right-hand access. As a reminder, the incremental 5% future acquisition of the new nuclear project from Santee Cooper will not affect these protected BLRA increases.
Please now turn to Slide 28. As mentioned in our third quarter call in September, the Public Service Commission approved a rate increase of $66.2 million. The new rates were effective for bills rendered on or after October 30. Our BLRA filings for 2015 are shown at the bottom of the slide. And you can see, we recently filed our quarterly status report for the fourth quarter.
That concludes our prepared remarks. We'll now be glad to respond to any questions you might have.

componenttext: For Steve, if I heard you correctly, you said that you'll be filing with the commission the updated schedule by the end of the first quarter. Is that in relation to missing the milestone with CA-03 at Unit 2 or is that a function of your expectation that you'll reach a settlement with the Consortium by then, or both? headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015

componenttext: Yes, the filings really are to update the cost and the schedule. I do not anticipate, at this point in time, that we will have a settlement with the Consortium when we file the updated petition by the end of the quarter. I could be surprised, but I would not anticipate that happening.

componenttext: No, I would think that it would be -- everything will depend on timing. But we will file a petition. We will have some period of time to generate testimony. We'll then have a formal hearing a few months later. And then at 6 months from the time we filed, the commission has to render their opinion. So it depends on when it will happen on that process. So obviously, if it were to happen before we went through here and we could amend the filing of the petition.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015

componenttext: Got it. Okay. Then my other question was, you mentioned the goal to stay out of rate cases during peak construction. Now that the peak construction has pushed out a few years and goes through 2017, is that still the hope to avoid a non-nuclear rate increase through 2017?

componenttext: That remains our goal.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015

componenttext: Okay, great. Then one last  one. When I look at the CapEx schedule you provided in the slides for new nuclear, it's -- I compare that to the appendix 2 of the BLRA. And they're usually pretty close, this time it seems like the CapEx numbers are more different than normal. Is there anything unusual going on between those 2?

componenttext: Just timing, Andrew. So we've just been pulling this all together very real time. headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Jim von Riesemann [ph] from Mizuho.
componenttext: The next question comes from Jim von Riesemann [ph] from Mizuho.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: A quick question for you. In the press release, you talked about the interest savings on the nuclear project. Am I thinking about this correctly that you have roughly $1.2 billion in potential interest rate savings versus the original project cost? So if
componenttext: A quick question for you. In the press release, you talked about the interest savings on the nuclear project. Am I thinking about this correctly that you have roughly $1.2 billion in potential interest rate savings versus the original project cost? So if that stays on plan, and let's assume a worst-case scenario where the $660 million construction dispute is -- goes against you -- the entire thing, so that's a real worst-case basis. Does that mean you're still under the original project cost and you're going to wind -- and the customers are not going to be impacted in any way?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I appreciate the question. And this is really the first time we've emphasized those interest savings. So we were really trying to clarify some misunderstanding, some in the financial markets and some in the local area here, where folks really weren'
componenttext: Well, I appreciate the question. And this is really the first time we've emphasized those interest savings. So we were really trying to clarify some misunderstanding, some in the financial markets and some in the local area here, where folks really weren't understanding the escalation savings. So we're projecting, as you know, in the BLRA somewhere around $575 million of lower escalation today than when we originally started the project. And sometimes, that had been confused with lower financing costs. That lower escalation is just lower escalation on the actual labor and modules, et cetera, associated with the construction, has nothing to do with the financing cost. So what we put in the press release is our estimate of the estimated savings over the tenor of the bonds that we have issued and those that we have locked in, the savings that would occur over the life of those. So they're really 2 different matters. As far as your real question about -- would the $660 million be offset by the $1.2 billion, I tell you it'd really be offset dollar for dollar by the escalation savings because those are more in today's dollars, the $1.2 billion are savings to occur over the future of the bonds, some 30-plus years.

componenttext: I don't -- there isn't any increased cost over the -- on what you presented previously. Also, remember though, that does not include owner's costs or escalation. That was referenced in 2007 dollars.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: We -- you're looking at, for that quarter, I think 2 things. One of them was burn rate for owner's costs and another one was for financing costs. On the owner's cost, I think you can assume we're very similar to them. The financing costs, however, their s
componenttext: We -- you're looking at, for that quarter, I think 2 things. One of them was burn rate for owner's costs and another one was for financing costs. On the owner's cost, I think you can assume we're very similar to them. The financing costs, however, their structure in Georgia, their contracts, the way they finance is a little different than the way we're financing. So I don't think you can make the assumption of financing costs. But on the owner's cost, the burn rate that they quoted, you can use roughly the same numbers for us.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. And also, a separate topic. The South Carolina Distributed Energy Resource Program, is there any opportunity for you guys to participate in solar build, regulated solar build in South Carolina?
componenttext: All right. And also, a separate topic. The South Carolina Distributed Energy Resource Program, is there any opportunity for you guys to participate in solar build, regulated solar build in South Carolina?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, there may be some opportunity. That's all being sorted out now. There's a process in front of the commission at this time. So there may be some opportunity in there, but it's really -- that's limited -- the whole legislation is aimed for South Caroli
componenttext: Yes, there may be some opportunity. That's all being sorted out now. There's a process in front of the commission at this time. So there may be some opportunity in there, but it's really -- that's limited -- the whole legislation is aimed for South Carolina as a state to get some good experience with renewables, not just solar, but with renewables in general. And the goal is -- or the requirement, really, is for 2% to be -- 2% of our generation to be in distributed, 1% utility, 1% in customer scale by 2020. So -- and we think those are a challenge to get done, but we think we will get them done. But there may be a small opportunity for us to participate in it. I expect there will be, but I don't think it will be material to our financial results.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015

componenttext: The next question comes from Travis Miller of Morningstar.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: A question back on the -- this filing that you're talking about by the end of the quarter and the timeline element. The cost thing, I can understand, you won't recover, et cetera. The timeline thing, is this more of a notification to the commission that t
componenttext: A question back on the -- this filing that you're talking about by the end of the quarter and the timeline element. The cost thing, I can understand, you won't recover, et cetera. The timeline thing, is this more of a notification to the commission that the timeline is different than originally approved? Or is there some implication here in terms of regulators looking in that timeline as outside of what was originally approved and, therefore, something happens and I would think, worst-case, something like a per-day fine or something like that? Does the schedule part of it being outside of that original approved bands have any implications?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Steve. The implications are we have to go through a formal hearing process, which is what the application that we would file by the end of the quarter kicks off. So in between then and 6 months later, when an order has to be issued, we'll have a h
componenttext: This is Steve. The implications are we have to go through a formal hearing process, which is what the application that we would file by the end of the quarter kicks off. So in between then and 6 months later, when an order has to be issued, we'll have a hearing. And that hearing, we'll have our opportunity to explain what happened with the Public Service Commission. It would have to really be imprudent before they would deny it. And imprudency on the part of us, the utility, which I think they would -- it would be very difficult for anybody to prove. And we have done this once before. So we've asked for a rebase line of our schedule once in the past and that was approved by the Public Service Commission by a 7-0 vote.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So they did rule imprudency based on the scheduled delays, then that would go into the cost side and potential recovery or nonrecovery, is that fair to think about like a gating factor, so to speak?
componenttext: Okay. So they did rule imprudency based on the scheduled delays, then that would go into the cost side and potential recovery or nonrecovery, is that fair to think about like a gating factor, so to speak?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure it would be a gating factor. I'm not sure exactly what they might do with it. I don't think it would be fair to assume they would just say no. But it is a hearing process and we will have to make our case for why the schedule extension is rea
componenttext: I'm not sure it would be a gating factor. I'm not sure exactly what they might do with it. I don't think it would be fair to assume they would just say no. But it is a hearing process and we will have to make our case for why the schedule extension is reasonable, which, certainly, we think we can make. But we'll be asking for what we pointed out today, so those new schedules. So this is our opportunity to explain that to the commission, because we're not allowed to have conversation with them outside of this formal hearing or an ex parte briefing process.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Travis, let me just add that -- I guess this is obvious to everyone, but what we'll be presenting is the future, not what's occurred behind us. So this is about permission, not about asking for forgiveness.
componenttext: Travis, let me just add that -- I guess this is obvious to everyone, but what we'll be presenting is the future, not what's occurred behind us. So this is about permission, not about asking for forgiveness.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Paul Patterson of Glen Rock Associates.
componenttext: The next question comes from Paul Patterson of Glen Rock Associates.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015

componenttext: Most of my questions have been answered. But just to refresh, you were talking to Ashar about this. The accretion associated with the asset sale, you're going to have a negative $0.04 now and then you're going to have that reversed and then you're going to have an accretion of $0.04, is that correct?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's correct. And maybe I can just summarize another way. One strategy we could have deployed is to take all the cash and go out and buy back shares today. And if that had happened, we would project the earnings for '15 would have been $0.08 higher, not
componenttext: That's correct. And maybe I can just summarize another way. One strategy we could have deployed is to take all the cash and go out and buy back shares today. And if that had happened, we would project the earnings for '15 would have been $0.08 higher, not $0.04 lower, but we would have been back to $3.74 plus $0.04 because of the accretion. We didn't think that strategy made a lot of sense given the valuation of the industry sector, given prices of stock today to go out and buy shares today and then go sell shares again 12, 18 months later. But just to try to clear that up, I thought I'd walk through that.

componenttext: Yes, we think we've seen some benefit from putting somebody on the ground of the Lake Charles facility, and so we wanted to do it a little earlier at the other facility. componenttext: Yes, so the best way to get the money back is not to pay it in the first place. So the contract has in it dispute resolution provisions, but we're trying to negotiate outside of that right now. And if that would have failed, then the contract provisions would kick in.
