componenttextpreview: Well, they've not published anything yet. I expect they will in the near term. But just to characterize the oral discussions, I think, it was generally neutral to positive with each of the agencies.
componenttext: Well, they've not published anything yet. I expect they will in the near term. But just to characterize the oral discussions, I think, it was generally neutral to positive with each of the agencies.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Can you just talk about -- and then lastly, could you talk about how the risk get rebucketed from -- under this settlement? I mean, obviously, you've absolved some of your own risk that you bore but how much -- what sort of risk would you say that y
componenttext: Okay. Can you just talk about -- and then lastly, could you talk about how the risk get rebucketed from -- under this settlement? I mean, obviously, you've absolved some of your own risk that you bore but how much -- what sort of risk would you say that you still retained and the risk that the construction consortium retains?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say our risk profile under either option is significantly enhanced. I mean, in fact, under the existing option that we've resolved all of these outstanding issues eliminates the risk of a potential litigation on those issues and the risks th
componenttext: Well, I would say our risk profile under either option is significantly enhanced. I mean, in fact, under the existing option that we've resolved all of these outstanding issues eliminates the risk of a potential litigation on those issues and the risks that are just inherent when going through that process over time. And I think the fact that we've significantly raised the liquidated damages gives us a lot more protection. Under the existing contractual arrangement, our liquidated damages are 6x what they were in the original contract. We still bear the risk of potential increased escalation and just increased interest expense during that time on the targeted dollars and the majority of dollars to be spent between now and the completion of the project are in that target bucket. But I think when you add them all of those together, our risk profile is certainly reduced from where it was before we signed the amendment. On the fixed-price option that we have in front of us, I think that really enhances our risk profile because we shift that escalation risk back to Westinghouse and our only risk would be changes in law or change orders that might be associated with the project. And we still got incentives payable under either option that would encourage them to complete the units on time. So anything that helps that happen in accordance with the schedule and the guarantee completion dates would lower our risk profile.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jim, I would -- this is Steve. I would give one implication to that. Under either scenario, I think we've enhanced our risk profile because where we get into commercial disputes with the consortium today, they largely revolve around the definition of a ch
componenttext: Jim, I would -- this is Steve. I would give one implication to that. Under either scenario, I think we've enhanced our risk profile because where we get into commercial disputes with the consortium today, they largely revolve around the definition of a change in law and they would use the term commercially driven -- or sorry, regulatory-driven change. And the language around changes that we've worked on and incorporated into this agreement significantly restricts what would be allowed as a regulatory-driven change. So we certainly improved it from that perspective. We also have a contract, the EPC contract. Remember, that was signed in about 2008, early '08, and that was based on the -- at that time, a current revision of the design certification document or DCD, which was Rev 16?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right.
componenttext: Right.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We were licensed to Rev 19. So they submitted a couple of revisions between signing it and the final approval. And so that has caused us some commercial issues in the interim. Now we resolved that with this agreement by updating the contract to DCD Rev 19
componenttext: We were licensed to Rev 19. So they submitted a couple of revisions between signing it and the final approval. And so that has caused us some commercial issues in the interim. Now we resolved that with this agreement by updating the contract to DCD Rev 19, which is what we're licensed to.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Jim, just so we all get to pitch in on this one, one other from a financial perspective. Under the old agreement, anytime we disputed an invoice, we paid 90% of it as you're aware. Under the new arrangement, if we dispute it, we don't pay anything and
componenttext: And Jim, just so we all get to pitch in on this one, one other from a financial perspective. Under the old agreement, anytime we disputed an invoice, we paid 90% of it as you're aware. Under the new arrangement, if we dispute it, we don't pay anything and we get a fairly rapid resolution from a resolution board. So we think that's a much better situation, too, to get all the parties to the table. And of course, there's one less party to get to the table than there was in the past.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So let me ask like a worst-case basis type question. So has Fluor and Westinghouse looked at the quality of the work that has been done by CB&I?
componenttext: So let me ask like a worst-case basis type question. So has Fluor and Westinghouse looked at the quality of the work that has been done by CB&I?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that Fluor has not had an opportunity to look at the quality. Fluor will not take over until the deal's effective. There is a period of time for regulatory approvals of the deal, standard stuff, perhaps complicated slightly by the fact that T
componenttext: Yes, I think that Fluor has not had an opportunity to look at the quality. Fluor will not take over until the deal's effective. There is a period of time for regulatory approvals of the deal, standard stuff, perhaps complicated slightly by the fact that Toshiba is a foreign entity. So there are regulatory approvals that need to take place. That's why we think that, that will be about a 45-day window and that's when Fluor really would have their first opportunity to assess things like quality. But Westinghouse has had an opportunity to assess quality as have of our folks. And so we don't just rely on the quality from the vendor, in this case, CB&I, we have our own quality group and our own quality inspectors. And we send our folks not just at the site, but we'll send them to facilities that are manufacturing components whether it be CB&I or somebody else and we'll send them whether it's domestically or internationally. Our QA/QC inspectors have got a lot of stamps in their passports. So we will be able to assure Fluor of the quality of the construction so far.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So you're happy with the quality. So there's going to be no aha moment is what you're saying.
componenttext: So you're happy with the quality. So there's going to be no aha moment is what you're saying.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we don't anticipate any aha moments.
componenttext: Yes, we don't anticipate any aha moments.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question will come from Travis Miller of Morningstar.
componenttext: The next question will come from Travis Miller of Morningstar.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Was wondering on this regulatory stuff in terms of the settlement. One, how much were regulators involved in this? And either at the federal level or nuclear level, the state level, was anybody involved? And what was that make up in terms of regulatory in
componenttext: Was wondering on this regulatory stuff in terms of the settlement. One, how much were regulators involved in this? And either at the federal level or nuclear level, the state level, was anybody involved? And what was that make up in terms of regulatory involvement?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: They were not directly involved in the negotiations. Certainly, we briefed the Office of Regulatory Staff before we made a final announcement of the settlement agreement. It was our commitment to the commission when we were in there earlier this year talk
componenttext: They were not directly involved in the negotiations. Certainly, we briefed the Office of Regulatory Staff before we made a final announcement of the settlement agreement. It was our commitment to the commission when we were in there earlier this year talking about the contract changes and getting the approvals at the time for the existing contract that we would come back to them and let them know of any changes in the status of the project. So we expect to be before the commission here in the near future in an ex parte communication, which is the quickest way for us to get in front of them and educate them on more of the details of the contractual amendments involved and how the options would work for the company going forward. And of course, once we make final decision, we'd be obligated to go back and make that filing to adjust the timetables and the guarantee -- excuse me, and the costs associated with it.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. You answered most of my second question there in terms of the regulatory process there. But is there a chance that regulators could deny the settlement and say it's not in customers' interests?
componenttext: Okay. You answered most of my second question there in terms of the regulatory process there. But is there a chance that regulators could deny the settlement and say it's not in customers' interests?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Certainly, they've got that option. Every time we go in, our commission has been very supportive of what we've done on this project in the past. They view it as critical not just to provide energy to customers in South Carolina, but as a key component of
componenttext: Certainly, they've got that option. Every time we go in, our commission has been very supportive of what we've done on this project in the past. They view it as critical not just to provide energy to customers in South Carolina, but as a key component of our response to the 111(d) Clean Power Plan. So it's critical to not just us, but also for our partner, Santee Cooper. So we are -- we feel like we're within the guidelines of the challenges were put before us to try to complete the project. Depending on which option we elect, we will go back and present our case to the commission as to why we decided to continue down the same path or why we believe it's the best interest to elect the fixed option. And they've generally listened to our testimony and evaluated that and made a fair decision. I certainly can't guarantee that, but I feel like we would do a good job explaining our position to the commission in a way that they could make a very fair valuation of our election.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Correct. And what kind of time line would that be on?
componenttext: Correct. And what kind of time line would that be on?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: When we make the decision, once we make the filing, they have 6 months to render a decision. So if we were to make a decision, for example, to elect the fixed-price option in early June next year, they would have to make that decision by early December. S
componenttext: When we make the decision, once we make the filing, they have 6 months to render a decision. So if we were to make a decision, for example, to elect the fixed-price option in early June next year, they would have to make that decision by early December. So it's a 6-month window from start to finish.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question will come from Paul Patterson of Glenrock Associates.
componenttext: The next question will come from Paul Patterson of Glenrock Associates.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: Okay. Onto your next question about financing. No change in our philosophy of 50-50 debt and equity. We just need to get through the process of reassessing with Fluor, making our option choice, going to the commission and getting that approval hopefully and then recasting the payments accordingly and conform our financing schedule to that.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Paul, this is Steve. The discussion about a facility in Florida that was fabricating some of these submodules, that was going to be the case whether we stayed under the existing contract or go under either of the 2 options that we're proposing. So th
componenttext: Yes. Paul, this is Steve. The discussion about a facility in Florida that was fabricating some of these submodules, that was going to be the case whether we stayed under the existing contract or go under either of the 2 options that we're proposing. So there's a facility in Florida and they are moving that work from that facility in Florida back to the Lake Charles facility for the trailing unit. And for the leading unit, we're actually taking those components to our site and we're finishing the submodule fabrication there before we fab them into the larger modules.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And why is that? Why is it being moved from -- what was the reason for the change?
componenttext: And why is that? Why is it being moved from -- what was the reason for the change?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's 2 things. One it's that, that facility had some commercial issues between themselves and CB&I. And secondly, they had a lot of work to do, things were backing up. They did have some quality issues while they came up to speed and we just think
componenttext: I think it's 2 things. One it's that, that facility had some commercial issues between themselves and CB&I. And secondly, they had a lot of work to do, things were backing up. They did have some quality issues while they came up to speed and we just think we can do it more expeditiously at our site.

componenttext: Got it. Last thing, in looking at the CapEx schedule, the utility CapEx in North Carolina, at the gas utility there, seems like it's a good bit higher when we get out to 2017 and 2018. Can you talk about that, talk about the timing and plans for potential rate case filings. And how you would -- or are there other mechanisms that can give you rate relief after spending significant capital level there.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, obviously, the low price in natural gas has driven a lot of opportunity for industry, for electric generation from gas plants, et cetera, and that has certainly been the case in North Carolina. So we've had a lot of opportunities that have popp
componenttext: Yes. Well, obviously, the low price in natural gas has driven a lot of opportunity for industry, for electric generation from gas plants, et cetera, and that has certainly been the case in North Carolina. So we've had a lot of opportunities that have popped up. We have executed some contracts in the last quarter or 2 that have driven this need to enhance some of our existing plans to grow the transmission system. So that's what's really driving these numbers. And clearly, it's starting to drive down the earned return and so it will drive the need for a rate proceeding at some time in the near future. We've not made any final decisions on that, but I expect we will have some announcement around that in 2016.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: Yes, again haven't made any final decisions, but today I would say it's more likely your first scenario than the second.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me give you a little color on what we have changed. So we've made the best estimate we can on the nuclear as I described earlier for 2016 based upon the revised agreement. The other thing we've done is there are reductions in the SCE&G base electric b
componenttext: Let me give you a little color on what we have changed. So we've made the best estimate we can on the nuclear as I described earlier for 2016 based upon the revised agreement. The other thing we've done is there are reductions in the SCE&G base electric business just based upon our commitment to scrub the CapEx for that business and try to avoid any base electric rate increases. The other significant change is adding the CapEx to the North Carolina gas system, PSNC Energy, and so we added about $75 million in '16 and $146 million in '17 for PSNC. So those are the 3 large changes for '16, $135 million down in electric, $53 million -- $75 million up at PSNC and $115 million up in nuclear.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then I had a question on Slide 8, I'm on the customer -- sales and customer growth and again looking at last quarter's release, I realize these are 12 -- I'm looking at the table at the bottom for the kilowatt-hours. The last -- I realize this is 12
componenttext: Okay. Then I had a question on Slide 8, I'm on the customer -- sales and customer growth and again looking at last quarter's release, I realize these are 12 -- I'm looking at the table at the bottom for the kilowatt-hours. The last -- I realize this is 12 months ending numbers, but there are like big changes in the weather-normalized so the residential went from basically negative 30 basis points to a positive 170 and commercial from positive 30 to positive 140. And then conversely, the industrial went from 3.8% down to 2.3%. So are you seeing that kind of big changes from quarter-to-quarter? Or what -- can you give us more color on what's going on in the demand from the various customer segments?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We are seeing that kind of change from quarter-to-quarter. And I would tell you it probably has more to do with the slide before that on the economy than anything else in our opinion. Let me give you a little more depth on that. So as I said in my earlier
componenttext: We are seeing that kind of change from quarter-to-quarter. And I would tell you it probably has more to do with the slide before that on the economy than anything else in our opinion. Let me give you a little more depth on that. So as I said in my earlier prepared comments, there are 80,000 more South Carolinians working today than there were a year ago. The unemployment rate has dropped from 6.6% to 5.7%, but that only tells part of the story. The workforce has expanded 3%. So if the workforce were the same level today than it were a year ago, the unemployment rate would be less than 3% in South Carolina. So the industrial recruitment in the state has been a real home run. Our governor has made that central to her platform and she's been extremely successful and we've seen it in the RNC markets as a result of that; now contrast that to our north -- to North Carolina where the workforce has expanded 1.8%; contrast it to Georgia where it's actually slightly down, almost breakeven year-over-year. So South Carolina's really growing.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess kind of the concern, though, is the big slowdown in the industrial sectors and what that might mean going forward. Do you have any color to add as to why that dropped so much?
componenttext: I guess kind of the concern, though, is the big slowdown in the industrial sectors and what that might mean going forward. Do you have any color to add as to why that dropped so much?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't. I don't have any specific -- no large closings or anything like that, that has driven it that I'm aware of. I'm not too concerned about that in the short run. I know the pipeline of projects that we're talking about that could be coming around th
componenttext: I don't. I don't have any specific -- no large closings or anything like that, that has driven it that I'm aware of. I'm not too concerned about that in the short run. I know the pipeline of projects that we're talking about that could be coming around the corner. I was just met this week with 2 -- with our head of industrial area about 2 new potential large projects in the area. So I really don't have any specific concern there. I think some of those may be related to real-time pricing customers that chose to come off the system during the heat of the summer rather than pay some of the prices they might have had to pay.

componenttext: Critical path items both for Unit 2 and 3. So is the next one for Unit 2, that's CA-02 that you said is going to be placed in -- by first half of '16? Or is there something else before that?

componenttextpreview: Yes, the next one of the structural modules to be placed will be that CA-02 that you mentioned. The critical path right now on the units really is still running through the shield building. And we did place the first row of those shield building panels la
componenttext: Yes, the next one of the structural modules to be placed will be that CA-02 that you mentioned. The critical path right now on the units really is still running through the shield building. And we did place the first row of those shield building panels last quarter and we anticipate doing some more of those in the near future. But the critical path for the units, really for both units, still runs through that shield building, receive the shield building panels, fit up the shield building panels and then pouring concrete in the panels once they're in place and welded.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then if I think about the added costs of going from the amended EPC to the fixed-price option, it looks like it's around $500 million, I guess, of additional project costs. If I do the math from prior presentations, 2017 to 2019 CapEx is project
componenttext: Okay. And then if I think about the added costs of going from the amended EPC to the fixed-price option, it looks like it's around $500 million, I guess, of additional project costs. If I do the math from prior presentations, 2017 to 2019 CapEx is projected to be around $2 billion. So should I think that, that incremental $500 million effectively would fix the 2017 to 2019? If you're not going to make your decision necessarily until late 2016, then effectively you're really just fixing the 2017 to 2019 CapEx?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Mitchell, we are fixing if we elect the fix-price option, but it doesn't really correlate to any kind of a specific burn rate. Now remember, the real difference as you look there at about a $500 million difference that you point out, that really is
componenttext: Well, Mitchell, we are fixing if we elect the fix-price option, but it doesn't really correlate to any kind of a specific burn rate. Now remember, the real difference as you look there at about a $500 million difference that you point out, that really is the risk that the contractor will price in to fix it to us. So what you're doing is your paying a risk premium and then they're having to make assumptions around things like inflation or what the escalation rates are going to be. So that really is -- was a negotiated number, but it really is reflective of the risk that now the contractor will have to take on.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Mitchell, it's reflective of all payments made after June 15 of this year if we elect the fixed-price option. Anything we pay or have paid since June up until the time we elect that option we get credited for at 100%.
componenttext: And Mitchell, it's reflective of all payments made after June 15 of this year if we elect the fixed-price option. Anything we pay or have paid since June up until the time we elect that option we get credited for at 100%.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Mitchell, the CapEx schedule on Page 10, we've made our best estimate of how this amendment will affect the cash flow in the short term. But as Kevin said in his prepared comments, once this milestone payment schedules develop, we're going to have to
componenttext: And Mitchell, the CapEx schedule on Page 10, we've made our best estimate of how this amendment will affect the cash flow in the short term. But as Kevin said in his prepared comments, once this milestone payment schedules develop, we're going to have to conform the CapEx schedule, no matter which option we go with, to match that. So those numbers will change, I'm sure. I just don't know exactly how at this point.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sorry. They will change based on what?
componenttext: Sorry. They will change based on what?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The milestone payment schedule that Kevin covered earlier. He said we're going to develop this milestone payment schedule, it's going to be tied to specific milestones being accomplished and then we'll conform our CapEx and financing schedule to that depe
componenttext: The milestone payment schedule that Kevin covered earlier. He said we're going to develop this milestone payment schedule, it's going to be tied to specific milestones being accomplished and then we'll conform our CapEx and financing schedule to that depending upon which option we elect.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. But once the fixed-price option is elected, that milestone payment schedule won't matter so much?
componenttext: Okay. But once the fixed-price option is elected, that milestone payment schedule won't matter so much?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, it will.
componenttext: No, it will.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The milestone schedule is really critical because what we're going to do here for the next 4 or 5 months is develop the schedule. So there's clarity as to what needs to be completed for a payment to be made to Westinghouse. And so once that schedule is co
componenttext: The milestone schedule is really critical because what we're going to do here for the next 4 or 5 months is develop the schedule. So there's clarity as to what needs to be completed for a payment to be made to Westinghouse. And so once that schedule is completed, there'll be dollars assigned to that if we continue under the existing contract and then they'll be dollars assigned to that if we were going under the fixed-price contract. So the schedule will be remain in place under either option, but the payments that go along with it will be based on whether we take the fixed-price option or continue under the option we're working under today.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So to contrast that, we're not going to make any payments in the future after this payment schedule is agreed to based upon the calendar. They're going to be based upon actual results.
componenttext: So to contrast that, we're not going to make any payments in the future after this payment schedule is agreed to based upon the calendar. They're going to be based upon actual results.

Or what specific costs are you responsible for in the fixed-price option that you've laid out if you choose to go that way?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. The total fixed-price option would be $7.601 billion as we've laid out on Slide 26, I think it's the third or fourth line down. That would be the total expected project cost. Of that, the capital cost portion or the construction contract, EPC contra
componenttext: Okay. The total fixed-price option would be $7.601 billion as we've laid out on Slide 26, I think it's the third or fourth line down. That would be the total expected project cost. Of that, the capital cost portion or the construction contract, EPC contract, will be $6.757 billion. So the addition amount would be escalation to date on the existing work that's been done and then some additional dollars, the additional $20 million associated with the schedule moving out 2 months for owner's costs. But the bulk of that is fixed in the fixed-price contract and that would be based on the guaranteed substantial completion date. So if Unit 2, August of 2019 and Unit 3, August of 2020 and the liquidated damages are keyed off of each of those dates for specific units.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. But could you give us a sense of how much you would be exposed to and via what variable if you were to have, for instance, the shift off of that August 2019 and 2020 date? Just to kind of give us a sense of the magnitude there. I mean, I appreciat
componenttext: Got it. But could you give us a sense of how much you would be exposed to and via what variable if you were to have, for instance, the shift off of that August 2019 and 2020 date? Just to kind of give us a sense of the magnitude there. I mean, I appreciate that a lot of it would be presumably fixed, but...

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Julien, this is Steve. The only thing that would not be fixed would be the things that we would be responsible for outside of the EPC contract, so that would be our owner's costs and then the transmission. But we can finish the transmission even if the pl
componenttext: Julien, this is Steve. The only thing that would not be fixed would be the things that we would be responsible for outside of the EPC contract, so that would be our owner's costs and then the transmission. But we can finish the transmission even if the plants are not finished. So really, it comes down to just the owner's costs.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And can you remind us what that is per month?
componenttext: And can you remind us what that is per month?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're looking at a burn rate on owner's costs at somewhere in the range of $10 million a month.
componenttext: Yes, we're looking at a burn rate on owner's costs at somewhere in the range of $10 million a month.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm going to go back to depreciation a second, if you guys don't mind. So what were the assets that were changed in the depreciation line to get such a big number on an EPS basis? I'm sorry, I've forgotten them.
componenttext: I'm going to go back to depreciation a second, if you guys don't mind. So what were the assets that were changed in the depreciation line to get such a big number on an EPS basis? I'm sorry, I've forgotten them.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I don't know that you've forgotten it. I don't think it's been published anywhere, but we really did -- we refreshed our entire comprehensive depreciation study across the whole electric system. So it includes the T&D and the generation system.
componenttext: No, I don't know that you've forgotten it. I don't think it's been published anywhere, but we really did -- we refreshed our entire comprehensive depreciation study across the whole electric system. So it includes the T&D and the generation system.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: What -- I mean, so can you bucket which was -- might have been generation versus T&D? And then I'm trying to think of what your big generation assets are because you've got ones that already got a long useful life, right?
componenttext: What -- I mean, so can you bucket which was -- might have been generation versus T&D? And then I'm trying to think of what your big generation assets are because you've got ones that already got a long useful life, right?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're down to about 5 significant generating plants outside of new nuclear, and so I really can't give you the buckets here today, Jim. You can probably go to the PSC website and get more details on it publicly there. Again, big picture, Jim, it's tr
componenttext: Yes, we're down to about 5 significant generating plants outside of new nuclear, and so I really can't give you the buckets here today, Jim. You can probably go to the PSC website and get more details on it publicly there. Again, big picture, Jim, it's trying to match up the real expected lives to the depreciation schedule in that, for example, at our nuclear facilities, we would anticipate that as opposed to just a 20-year life extension, that we will be pursuing a second life extension. So that would take that plant out to 80 years total. And then we're using actual history on some of the plants that we've been operating and we're extending the depreciation scales out on those plants to again match up with what we really think is the useful life.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a quick follow-up. When we come down to the point of making decision between the fixed option and the current, would it make sense to get commission approval prior to choosing the fixed option? Or how should we think about that?
componenttext: Just a quick follow-up. When we come down to the point of making decision between the fixed option and the current, would it make sense to get commission approval prior to choosing the fixed option? Or how should we think about that?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, the way the process would work is we have an obligation to go back to the commission if there's a change in the price, the capital cost schedule that they've already approved. So either option would require us to go back to the commission at some poin
componenttext: No, the way the process would work is we have an obligation to go back to the commission if there's a change in the price, the capital cost schedule that they've already approved. So either option would require us to go back to the commission at some point. So we need to make an election of which option we believe is superior so we can go back to the commission and ask for approval of that option. It wouldn't be likely that we would go back to the commission and say tell us which one you like and we'll head down that road. They'll look for us to make a recommendation, a specific recommendation to them.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And when can we expect that to happen?
componenttext: And when can we expect that to happen?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We have 12 months from the effective date to make that option. So excuse me, it runs through November 1, 2016. That's a specific date in the contract.
componenttext: We have 12 months from the effective date to make that option. So excuse me, it runs through November 1, 2016. That's a specific date in the contract.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: Well, thank you very much, and certainly so far this year has been very eventful. We're very pleased with our progress with the resolution to the negotiations and with our financial results through the first 3 quarters. We continue to focus on the new nuclear construction and on operating all of our business in safe and reliable manner. And we thank you all for joining us today and for your interest in SCANA. Have a good day.
